content: The Export Promotion Enhancement Act of 2008 establishes duties, strategic plans, and a Trade Promotion Advisory Board. It includes findings and conforming amendments to other laws. Congress finds that the United States, as the world's largest economy, has a significant interest in the global trading system. Exports drive the US economy and job creation, with small and medium enterprises accounting for a large portion of exporters. However, there is room for growth as many small manufacturers do not currently export but would consider doing so with more assistance. United States small and medium enterprises face tough competition from trading partners with aggressive export promotion programs. Trade promotion in the US involves 21 federal departments and agencies, but the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee has not effectively provided export promotion products and services due to resource allocation issues. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee faces challenges in providing export promotion services due to resource allocation issues and lack of decision-making authority. The purpose of this Act and its amendments is to enhance trade promotion policies and programs of the Federal Government in line with the Government Performance and Results Act of 1993. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to establish the Office of Trade Promotion in the Executive Office of the President, to coordinate and oversee trade promotion activities. The amendments also include supervising the implementation of trade promotion policies. In subsections (b) through (f), replace "TPCC" with "Office". SEC. 102. DUTIES. Section 2312(b) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to advise the President on trade promotion policies, supervise coordination, and focus on measurable results in service delivery. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to advise the President on trade promotion policies, supervise coordination, and focus on measurable results in service delivery, including assistance to match United States businesses with foreign businesses. The amendment also aims to prevent unnecessary duplication and enhance the effectiveness of resource allocation among agencies in support of export promotion and financing. The concurrence in allocations is based on a review. SEC. 103. STRATEGIC PLAN. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include detailed benchmarks for implementing priorities, improve coordination effectiveness, and include a detailed plan in the annual Federal budget submission to Congress for oversight and support of implementation. Amendments are made to Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 by adding "and" after the semicolon, changing "and" to a period in paragraph (5), and striking paragraph (6). SEC. 104. DIRECTOR AND ASSOCIATE DIRECTORS. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include a Director and Associate Directors for the Office of Trade Promotion, appointed by the President with Senate approval and compensated accordingly. The Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include a Director and Associate Directors for the Office of Trade Promotion, appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Associate Directors shall be compensated at a rate not to exceed that of other associate directors within the Executive Office of the President and perform functions as prescribed by the Director. SEC. 105. STAFF; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. Section 2312 of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to allow the Director of the Office to appoint additional personnel and request staff from federal agencies to assist in carrying out duties. Experts and consultants can also be appointed by the Director. The Director of the Office can procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the maximum annual rate of basic pay for GS-15 of the General Schedule. SEC. 106. ADVISORY BOARD ON TRADE PROMOTION. The Advisory Board on Trade Promotion is established by the President to advise the Director of the Office in carrying out duties under the Export Enhancement Act. Members of the Advisory Board include representatives from various sectors. The Advisory Board on Trade Promotion, established by the President to advise the Director of the Office under the Export Enhancement Act, includes representatives from various government departments and agencies. The Advisory Board on Trade Promotion, established by the President under the Export Enhancement Act, includes representatives from various government departments and agencies such as the Millennium Challenge Corporation, Office of Management and Budget, Overseas Private Investment Corporation, Small Business Administration, Trade and Development Agency, and Office of the United States Trade Representative. The Secretary of Commerce serves as the chairperson of the Advisory Board. Members of the Advisory Board must meet certain qualifications. The Advisory Board on Trade Promotion, established by the President under the Export Enhancement Act, includes representatives from various government departments and agencies. Members must have significant decision-making authority in their respective departments or agencies. The Environmental Trade Promotion section amends the Export Enhancement Act to rename the Trade Promotion Coordination Committee to the Advisory Board on Trade Promotion. The Export Enhancement Act renames the Trade Promotion Coordination Committee to the Advisory Board on Trade Promotion. The chairperson of the Advisory Board is required to submit a report on the Working Group's activities to the Director of the Office of Trade Promotion for inclusion in the annual report to Congress. The Environmental technologies trade advisory committee is also affected by the changes. The Export Enhancement Act renames the Trade Promotion Coordination Committee to the Advisory Board on Trade Promotion and updates references to "TPCC" to "Advisory Board" and "Office of Trade Promotion" in relevant sections. SEC. 107 of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 requires the Director of the Office to submit an annual report to Congress detailing the strategic plan, its implementation, revisions, and funding appropriateness to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House of Representatives. SEC. 108 amends Section 2314(b)(1)(B) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 to include the report of the Director of the Office of Trade Promotion containing the strategic plan submitted to Congress. SEC. 109 authorizes appropriations. SEC. 109 authorizes appropriations for fiscal year 2008 and subsequent years to carry out specific sections of the Export Enhancement Act and the FREEDOM Support Act. Amounts appropriated are authorized to remain available until expended. SEC. 110 makes a clerical amendment. SEC. 110 of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to change the heading to "office of trade promotion." The President must establish the Office of Trade Promotion within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 201 makes conforming amendments to other laws. The Export Enhancement Act of 1999 is amended to change references from "Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee" to "Office of Trade Promotion" and make adjustments to the FREEDOM Support Act. The Export Enhancement Act of 1999 is amended to change references from "Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee" to "Office of Trade Promotion" and make adjustments to the FREEDOM Support Act by amending section 304. The Export Enhancement Act of 1999 is amended to change references from "Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee" to "Office of Trade Promotion" in Section 304. Any mention of the Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee or TPCC in US laws, regulations, or records will now refer to the Office of Trade Promotion.
